texts.text: Every day is painful for me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Painful?
She nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What would you do?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hm?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If you could go back to those days you can't get back, what would you do differently?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hmm...
I remember the anthology I found yesterday.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I would have written more of what I wanted to write. I would have stopped trying to keep up appearances, and maybe...

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Maybe I could have written like your father did.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Maybe my worldview would have expanded, and I could have met more diverse kinds of people.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Why can't you start doing that now?
She's looking into my eyes again.
Those innocent eyes seem to shine from within.
I simply stare back at her guileless expression, stunned.
She giggles.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If that's how you feel, I think you should just go ahead and write.
I shake my head.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's too late. Everything about me has become dull. I don't have any spark left.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't think you're quite as old and decrepit as you think.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You don't quite see yourself as an adult either, though. That's why you chose to stay in education as a teacher, and just let the time go by.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Maybe you're right.
She lets out a little laugh.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It's just writing. Whether you write or not, either way, the world won't change.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That was true for my father as well.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I think you could treat it more casually. Like humming a song you like.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Especially in your case.
Rin looks down at her food and continues eating away.
No, Hatano Shuho definitely changed the world.
Of course, most pieces of media don't change the world. But isn't Shuho the exception to that?
I finish up the rest of my soba as the thoughts stew in my mind.
Sipping the last of the broth, I look back up at her.
I recall the picture of Hatano Shuho that I saw yesterday.
There's a certain resemblance.
She returns my stare.
And then, the first pre-class bell rings.
She still has half her meal left.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Again, sorry for bothering you during lunch time.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: No, it's fine. I'm glad we talked.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Me too. See you at the library.
Rin nods and resumes eating the rest of her lunch.
I stand and pick up my tray.
I watch him as he goes.
Why did I say all that?
I'm fine?
I don't feel lonely even if I'm alone?
Aren't they exactly the kind of things a person says when they want someone to realize they're not okay?
It's not like he even asked me.
Did I want my teacher to worry about me?
Did I want him to know that I know how solitude feels?
I don't know.
I look down at my tray.
There's a bit of mackerel meat left by the tail.
The miso soup has gone cold already.
It doesn't matter.
When you eat alone, it doesn't really matter if the food is hot or cold.
I bite into the last bit of fish.
Now that I think about it, it's been a long time since I last talked with someone over a meal.
In the end, why did he decide to talk to me?
As I stare vacantly ahead while eating, I see the professor coming back with his tray.
I look up at his face as he comes closer.
Rin's face is getting closer and closer.
I mulled over whether or not I should ask her.
Writing doesn't change the world.
That's what she said, and she's probably right.
Maybe I'm just overthinking all this.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm sorry, yesterday, I actually...
Rin looks puzzled.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I found something your dad wrote back in college. I'll bring it in if you want to read it.
She's looking up at me, clearly surprised.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If you're interested in what he was like back in his college days, I think reading that would be better than anything I can tell you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Don't worry, I just happened to find it, and...
After a moment, the corners of her mouth rise into a bright smile.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thank you. I'd like that very much.
I answer with a nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It kind of feels like I do nothing but borrow stuff from you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Huh? Oh, right.
The umbrella.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Don't worry about it. It doesn't do me any good to have it, anyway.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But you need the umbrella for the rain, right?
She giggles again.
For some reason, I seem to start fumbling around her.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm looking forward to reading it.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'll bring it to the library tomorrow.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thanks.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: So, uh... See you.
I turn around and walk away.
Afternoon classes end at fifth period today, so I decide to go straight back home.
I wash my hands and head to my room.
I put down my bag, sit at my desk, and look at the anthology.
I check the table of contents again.
I see something that brings back a lot of memories.
My old pen name.
I almost forgot. This anthology contains my work as well as Shuho's. Side by side.
First, I open it to the page where my piece starts.
My work describes Meiji-Dori in winter, from the perspective of a single ginkgo tree standing beside the bustling city road.
As I keep reading, I remember more and more of what I was thinking at the time.

I tried to depict the drama of the various characters who pass by, and how the tree adds color to the street and life to the background of the myriad little stories that occur in everyday life. But I failed.
The professor told me that the idea wasn't a bad one, but the themes were too sprawling for the limited number of pages I had to work with.
In my youthful excess, I tried to write something bigger than everyone else.
There are also some pretentious metaphors in it that make me cringe in embarrassment.
But Watanabe was right; the passage of time really reminds me that the person who wrote this back then isn't the person I am today.
And then, there's Hatano Shuho's contribution.
He wrote a first person narrative about how he skipped a lecture one day to make a round trip from Takadanobaba to Sakuragicho.
It's a concise and short work that describes the shifting scenery in a very matter-of-fact manner.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Sakuragicho...
I look up from the book.
There's something about the place name that makes me think.
After a moment, I remember the information about him that I found on the web.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Somewhere in Yokohama, huh?
The location of that nighttime view on his book's cover.
Maybe Sakuragicho was already a special spot for him by this point.
I wonder if Rin knows about this.
Maybe she'll be able to glean something from what he wrote back when he was a simple college student.
I look down at his prose again.
Although he's not writing about himself or his ego in this piece, I can feel something true in it.
Reading the text he wrote, for the first time, I feel like I could reach out and touch the scenery he's trying to evoke.
In comparison, my writing was rough, stilted, and shoddy.
I feel like I could write something better now.
But that faint flicker of hope is quickly dashed.
There is no talent in me. There never was.
At this point, Shuho had already found his way of writing.
Even if it's a little unrefined at this point.
Compared to his debut novel, it feels like he's still feeling it out to find a style that fits him best.
I close the anthology.
I don't think I'll read it anymore.
I'll give it to Rin as soon as possible.
I put the book in my bag, and after a moment of hesitation, decide to do the same with the album.
The next day after classes, I find Rin is already in the library before me.
I sit in front of her.
She closes the novel she's reading and puts it on the desk.
It's another book by her dad.
I hand over the anthology and photo album to her.
She stares down at the album for a moment before slowly looking back up at me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What is this?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Photos from a party that was held back when your dad won the Rookie Award.
Rin stares at me blankly and blinks a few times.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Why?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It shows your dad back when he was young. Thought you might like to have it.
She looks down again and stares at the album's cover.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Can I look inside?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Go ahead.
She takes the album and opens it up.
She flips through the pages with a little smile on her face.
I watch her.
After a few pages, she looks back at me.
Her rose eyes have a faint glimmer to them.
Then, again, she turns that bright gaze back to the album.
She's looking at the picture of me and my wife.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: A girlfriend?
I think for a second and then give her a weak nod.
She tilts her head and looks at me curiously.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Wife.
Her eyes widen in obvious surprise.
Then she pulls the album in closer and looks at the picture for a good while.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: She's very pretty.
Then she looks up at me again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Looks like you got lucky, huh?
Not knowing how to answer, I simply nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Heheh.
Ring laughs out loud.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Your dad is in that picture too. That's why I brought it.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Oh, you're right.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What kind of person is she?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Huh?
She looks into my eyes.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Your wife.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Uh... She's an editor, and she's pretty good at it, I think.
The smile disappears from her face.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's not what I meant.
There's a tinge of annoyance in her tone.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm not asking about her profession. What's she like as a person? What drew you to her?
I don't think she realizes how tough these questions are.
Her curious gaze is set squarely on me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: She...
Rin waits patiently for me to keep going.
I search for the words, but then I remember something.
The day that picture was taken...
The day we celebrated Shuho's award...
Shouko said she wanted to read my novels.
She said that to me, not to him.
That's why I...
I asked her to marry me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Professor?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I don't remember.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You're a terrible liar.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That's just how married couples are.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: We've been together for twenty-one years.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: How we got together doesn't really matter to us anymore.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You can't cover your lies with eloquence.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Or with silence.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: What do you want from me?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Ahahah.
She laughs out loud again.
I even get a glimpse of her white teeth.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: She's an editor, right?
I nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Then she must like books, same as you.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Maybe.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Maybe?
As she repeats after me, I realize something.
I haven't seen her reading a book in years.
There aren't any books in our living room either.
Maybe she just stopped reading finished works after publishing became her job?
Or maybe we don't even share our private life anymore at this point.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Our schedules are out of sync. Maybe she reads when I'm not around.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Back then, we did like the same kind of books.
I point to the album.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What kind is that?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Novels.
She stares at me, her inquisitive gaze urging me to continue.
I reel off a list of Meiji era novelists I was into at the time.
She nods deeply as I list the names for her.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'll try reading them.
I nod back at her.
She then takes a look at the rest of the album.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This does feel kind of different.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Different how?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It was an award party, right?
I nod in response.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I never saw him this happy about writing something in my life.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It's... new to me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Maybe it's the difference between a pro and an amateur.
She nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Maybe, yes.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So he had moments like these once upon a time.
She remarks, then closes the album.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But I don't think I can take this.
Rin presents the album to me.
I stare at the album sitting between the two of us on the table.
Then I look at her.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I appreciate your concern. I'll remember how he looked in these pictures.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But I think you need this more than I do.
She keeps her eyes on mine as she reaches out for the anthology next.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This is an anthology collection, right?
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Your dad also wrote something for it. Might be worth a lot of money.
Rin nods and begins flipping the pages.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Did you write something in here too?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: No.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Oh...
I wrote under a pseudonym.
She won't know I'm lying.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Your dad was writing using his real name since all the way back then.
She nods and flips the pages.
I watch her read for a while then open up a book of my own and get reading myself.
She keeps reading the anthology until it's time to leave the library.
It seems like she read all of the contributions, instead of just Shuho's.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thank you.
Rin thanks me after closing the book.
I just nod in response.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: How was it? Did you learn anything?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I was a little surprised by his writing style in this.
I nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But the fundamentals are the same as in his later works.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Agreed.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It felt like he had already found the way he wanted to write.
Rin nods and begins eyeing Shuho's text from the beginning again.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Are you gonna be a writer too?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You read it all, right?
I point at the anthology.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Most normal hobbyist readers don't go sifting through anthologies of amateur material.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's mostly aspiring writers who want to measure up their abilities.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Really? I thought it was really fun to read.
I shake my head.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: The only one who made an impression and pushed past this stage was your dad.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: He was the only one who made it as a writer.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What about the person who wrote the ginkgo tree story?
I stare at her for a moment, speechless.
Noticing my silence, she raises her gaze from the collection.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This person didn't become a writer either, then.
She flips through the pages and opens my story.
I stare at the page.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...They didn't.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I see.
She keeps reading my writing in silence.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why do you ask?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That person's one of the ordinary writers. Unlike Shuho.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I don't think their work is any different from any of the others.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You knew this person?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I did.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What kind of person were they?
For a moment, the possibility that she's just making fun of me crosses my mind.
But she looks genuinely curious.
There is no malice behind her words.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: They tried to become a professional writer, but I guess they stopped after graduating from college.
Rin nods and then looks back at my writing.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm glad.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You... are?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why?
My voice comes out louder than I expected.
Rin puts a finger to her mouth.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: This person is probably...
She slowly raises her face to look at me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: ...a lot like my father.
I can't sleep.
Her words keep echoing in my head.
I'm like Hatano Shuho?
How?
We couldn't be more diametrically opposed.
Rin...
What did she think of my writing?
Shuho was never a parent to her.
And he never left her a place to belong.
That's what she said.
The thoughts revolve around my head one after the other.
And each time, my mind becomes clearer.
She said that she was glad I didn't continue writing.
But if I resembled Shuho, wouldn't it have been better to keep writing?
What in the world did Hatano Shuho mean to Rin?
She said she didn't know.
She doesn't know anything about her father.
That's why she's reading his work.
I get up from bed.
I pace about the living room and light a cig.
I gaze up at the smoke as it rises and is sucked up by the ventilation fan.
The mystery that is Hatano Shuho keeps growing in my mind.
During my student days, I wished countless times that I could become like him.
To be appreciated like he was, earn the money he did, and write for a living.
I wished for that so many times.
In the end, all I felt for him was admiration and envy.
I can accept that now.
Even though twenty years have passed since then, my head is full of him all over again.
It's weird.
I stub out my cigarette and light another.
I stare as the red ring consuming it illuminates my face slightly.
It doesn't shine bright like a burning flame, but I can still feel its smoldering warmth.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...Maybe I can write.
I mutter to myself.
I could chase the Shuho inside of me, and draw from that idol to make my main character.
The answer is inside of me.
At least, his character from my point of view is.
My own idealized image, given form by the side of Shuho that I saw.
It would become my own objective vision.
It would be my definition of him.
I might be able to write something out of this.
In fact, I feel an overwhelming need to put these feelings to paper.
It's been so long since I felt this way.
Writing this could save me.
And...
Rin may read it.
Maybe she could discover something from reading my writing.
Maybe she would look less desolate all the time.
The image of a lonely Rin eating by herself at a huge table in a corner of an empty mansion crosses my mind.
That loneliness she's experiencing isn't her fault.
Someone needs to help her.
And while I don't know if I can be the one to do that, I can at least try.
On that campus, where everyone is innocently enjoying college life, there's someone else like me. Someone who feels like they're sinking into the depths of the darkest ocean.
I let myself get stuck there.
And I can struggle out one more time.
My chest feels hot.
A small but true flame burns inside of me.
I'm smoking another cigarette as I boil water.
It's one thing to decide to write again. It's another thing to figure out how to go about it.
I still want to do a depiction of Shuho.
But his image is too big, too broad.
First I need to figure out what side of him I want to capture.
He has become something akin to an idol from my perspective, but his true self still eludes me.
No matter how I try, I can't get a grip on the reality.
As I sit in the kitchen, smoking, my eyes fall on the album I dropped on the coffee table yesterday.
I hear the electric kettle click off as the water reaches a boil.
I put out the cig and finish the coffee.
Then I settle on the sofa with my mug.
I open the album and look through the photos.
The only pictures with me and Shuho together are one I took with my wife, and one of the group as a whole.
He's smiling in every photo.
It occurs to me that while I've spent so long being envious of Shuho, this was the only time our paths actually crossed.
I look at the album again.
It's strange.
He feels like such a normal person here.
If I can take the man in these photos and supplement it with my own imagination, I might get something worthwhile.
If I start with this party and follow his life as an ordinary young man, I might be able to visualize the outline of what I need.
I'm twenty years older than he was at that time.
That should let me maintain some objectivity.
And the scale should be just about right.
If I can make my image of Shuho clearer, I'll be able to compare ourselves more easily.
I'll be able to see if there are similarities, and the differences will be more apparent.
I finish my coffee in no time.
I'd forgotten what writing felt like for me; a process of indirectly sorting things out in my head.
The outline of what I want to write becomes clearer and clearer.
I always loved this feeling.
Time to put some words to paper.
I'm not even thinking about whether Rin will read it anymore.
I just feel like finally unloading all this toxic negativity that has been piling up for years inside me.
And for that, I need to write.
It's the 1990s.
A certain bar in the student district.
I start writing, checking the album from time to time to refresh my memory.
The bar is cheerful and bustling.
The beer on tap is tasteless and barely carbonated, but at least it's cold.
The whole place smells of the fermented seafood traditionally eaten with booze.
It's all coming back to me now.
There are about thirty people there.
The star of the night is Hatano Shuho, who just won major publisher's rookie award while studying in university.
Every person there is looking at him, thinking about him.
I'm no exception.
I arrived late, then congratulated Shuho like everyone else.
He answered with a smile and a hearty word of thanks.
Then I took a seat in a corner and drank my beer alone.
After about thirty minutes, the seminar's teacher and a veteran of the publishing world said a few words. Then Shuho spoke of his future aspirations, and we went our separate ways.
I write about the day just as it happened.
Later, Shuho was taken to an after-party.
I wasn't there, so I can't go on memory.
From this point on, it's all speculative fiction.
But the things I do know lend atmosphere to my speculation.
I can write this.
As I start to gain momentum, I think back on what I was doing at the same time.
After a moment, I remember.
I slipped out that day with my future wife, and we spoke in a family restaurant until just before the last train ran.
The more I think about it, the more strange it becomes.
Even back then, my wife had her mind set on becoming an editor.
Why would she abandon her chance to talk to Shuho to hang out with me instead?
I don't know.
I've no idea what she was feeling at the time.
A thought strikes me, to follow this other pair as well.
That party was the only time my path and Shuho's ever crossed.
If I started writing about myself using this party as a starting point, what would come out?
I notice the thoughts bubbling up in the back of my mind, and push them out.
Losing focus is a bad habit of mine.
I picture Tadakanobaba Station as it was back in those days.
Full of night traffic and noisy students.
Drunken freshman sleeping on the road, upperclassmen belting out their school songs.
I imagine Hatano Shuho walking through such a scene.
And I keep writing.
